name: Calcium
summary: An essential mineral for bone health, muscle contraction, nerve signaling, and cardiovascular stability, sometimes used as adjunctive support in mood and anxiety disorders.
description: Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the human body, with over 99% stored in bones and teeth. It plays critical roles in skeletal integrity, neuromuscular function, intracellular signaling, and blood clotting. While primarily recognized for preventing osteoporosis, calcium has also been studied in psychiatry, particularly in relation to premenstrual syndrome (PMS), mood regulation, and anxiety. Supplementation is widely available but should be balanced with other minerals, particularly magnesium and vitamin D, to optimize absorption and minimize cardiovascular risks.

metadata.natural_source: Dairy products, leafy greens, fortified foods
metadata.fda_status: Recognized as a dietary supplement and nutrient of concern

Hypertension prevention (in combination with other nutrients)

sections.text: Calcium is vital for bone mineralization and structural strength. It also functions as a secondary messenger in neurons, regulates neurotransmitter release, and is necessary for muscle contraction and cardiac rhythm stabilization. Calcium supplementation may help stabilize mood and reduce PMS symptoms by modulating neuronal excitability and hormonal signaling.

adult.typical: 1000–1200 mg daily (from diet and supplements combined)
adult.note: Best absorbed in doses ≤500 mg, taken with meals; calcium citrate has better absorption than calcium carbonate in patients with low stomach acid.

sections.pediatric: 500–1300 mg daily depending on age and growth stage
sections.geriatric: 1200 mg daily recommended, often with vitamin D supplementation

sections.text: Bone health effects require months to years of consistent intake. PMS symptom relief may occur within 2–3 cycles.

serious: Possible increased cardiovascular risk with very high doses

other: Avoid exceeding 2000–2500 mg daily to reduce kidney stone and cardiovascular risks.
Calcium should be balanced with magnesium and vitamin D for proper absorption and utilization.

items: Bone mineral density (if used for osteoporosis)

sections.pregnancy: Safe and essential; reduces risk of preeclampsia when adequate
sections.geriatrics: Beneficial for bone preservation but monitor for cardiovascular risk

sections.text: Not required. Discontinuation may gradually increase risk of bone loss.

items: Vitamin D is required for optimal calcium absorption.
Excess calcium from supplements, but not diet, may be associated with increased cardiovascular risk.
May improve PMS-related mood swings and bloating in women with low dietary calcium.
